The Docket: Legal Document Card Concepts
This list maps the effects of Balatro's Tarot cards to specific legal documents, creating a new thematic set to replace the "Academy" cards.
Card Effect
column3: Thematic Rationale

column1: Creates a copy of the last consumable card used
column3: A literal, official duplicate of a document you just used, ready to be entered into the record again.

column1: Enhances 2 selected cards to Lucky Cards
column3: You're asking the court to take another look at your evidence, introducing an element of luck and hoping for a favorable outcome.

column1: Creates up to 2 random Alchemy cards
column3: A powerful court order that imposes new rules and conditions on the case, perfectly represented by creating new "Alchemy" rule cards.

column1: Enhances 2 selected cards to Mult Cards
column3: You're applying a powerful, established legal ruling to your current evidence, making it significantly more persuasive.

column1: Creates up to 2 random Docket cards
column3: A real type of subpoena that commands someone to produce documents, literally generating more cards for "The Docket."

column1: Enhances 2 selected cards to Bonus Cards
column3: A sworn statement from an expert that adds foundational weight and credibility (Bonus Chips) to your evidence.

column1: Enhances 1 selected card into a Wild Card
column3: A retroactive court order that corrects a past record. It's like retroactively changing a card's suit to be whatever you needed it to be.

column1: Enhances 1 selected card into a Steel Card
column3: A notary's seal makes a document official, durable, and hard to dispute, just like a Steel card.

column1: Enhances 1 selected card into a Glass Card
column3: A powerful, one-time piece of evidence that can win the argument on its own but is consumed in the process.

column1: Doubles Money (Max of $20).
column3: The contract a client signs to secure your services, often involving a significant upfront payment.

column1: 1 in 4 chance to add an edition
column3: The inherent power of a judge to make a ruling based on their own judgment. This card represents a random boon granted by the judge.

column1: Gives the total sell value of all partners
column3: A court order to convert all assets (your partners) into their cash value.

column1: Enhances 1 selected card into a Gold Card
Enhances 1 selected card into a Stone Card/ EXHIBIT
column3: A sworn, out-of-court testimony that becomes a solid, foundational, and unchangeable part of the case record.

column1: Converts up to 3 cards to one suit
column2: Change of Venue (to Location), Character Witness (to Suspect), Forensics Report (to Weapon)
column3: Specific legal actions that focus the case on one aspect, converting other evidence to match that focus.

column1: Converts up to 3 selected cards into Suitless
column3: A court order that strips a witness of their criminal liability, removing their most defining characteristic.

column1: Creates a random Partner card
column3: The official legal body recommends a new partner for your firm.

column1: Select 2 cards, convert the right card into the left
column3: A contract term stating that this new agreement merges with and supersedes all previous ones. The left card's identity supersedes the right one.

column1: Destroys up to 2 selected cards
column3: A formal request to a judge to have evidence or testimony removed from the court record.
A legal claim placed on an asset (a card) to secure a debt, making it valuable in a monetary sense.

column1: Legal Fictions: Spectral Card Concepts
This list maps the high-risk, high-reward nature of Balatro's Spectral cards to the theme of "Legal Fictions"—powerful, reality-bending legal principles.
Spectral Card Effect (Example)
column3: Thematic Rationale

column1: Duplicates a random Joker
column3: The legal fiction that a corporation can be treated as a person. This card "creates a new person" for your firm by duplicating a partner. Negative: Destroys 2 random cards.

column1: Creates 4 random Tarot cards
column3: The law often judges actions against a hypothetical "reasonable person." This card summons the judgments of four such phantoms. Negative: Lowers max hand size by 1.

column1: Makes 1 Joker have a 1 in 2 chance of being destroyed
column3: The doctrine that a fugitive from justice cannot access the court system. This partner is now "on the run," and you might lose access to them. Positive: The targeted partner gives x3 Mult.

column1: All cards become one rank
column3: An old legal status where a person loses all their rights, as if they were dead. All your cards lose their individual identity and are reduced to one. Positive: This hand gets +200 Chips.

column1: Destroys all Jokers and gives money
column3: The government's power to seize private property for public use. Your partners are "seized" for the greater good of your wallet. Positive: Gain $50.

column1: Applies a random seal to every Joker
column3: An ancient doctrine concerning property held by an institution in perpetuity. The "dead hand" of the past reaches out to permanently mark all of your partners. Negative: All partners are debuffed until one is sold.

column1: Extra-Judicial Measures: Spectral Card Concepts

This list maps the high-risk, high-reward nature of Balatro's Spectral cards to the theme of "Extra-Judicial Measures"—powerful, dangerous, and often unethical actions taken outside the normal rules of court.
Spectral Card Effect (Example)
column3: Thematic Rationale

column1: Duplicates a random Joker
column3: You've hired a brilliant but disbarred attorney to secretly work on the case, effectively "duplicating" a partner's skills. Negative: The risk of discovery is high, forcing you to destroy 2 random cards to cover your tracks.

column1: Creates 4 random Tarot cards
column3: You've made a risky attempt to influence the jury, resulting in a flood of new procedural opportunities (Docket cards). Negative: The judge is suspicious, lowering your max hand size by 1.

column1: Makes 1 Joker have a 1 in 2 chance of being destroyed
column3: You're relying on an informant from the criminal underworld. Their information is incredibly valuable (x3 Mult), but they are unreliable and might disappear at any moment.

column1: All cards become one rank
column3: You've scared a key witness into changing their story. All your cards now conform to a single, simple narrative. Positive: The simplicity of the story makes it powerful, granting a large Chip bonus.

column1: Destroys all Jokers and gives money
column3: You've convinced your entire team of partners to dissolve the firm and take a massive payout, abandoning the case entirely.

column1: Applies a random seal to every Joker
column3: You've made a secret deal with the opposing counsel that has permanent, unforeseen consequences for every partner at your firm. Negative: All partners are debuffed until one is sold to "pay the price" of the deal.

column1: Contempt of Court: Spectral Card Concepts
This list maps the spectral card effects to the theme of "Contempt of Court"—powerful, dangerous, and often unethical actions that defy the rules of the courtroom for a major advantage.
Spectral Card Effect
column3: Thematic Rationale

column1: Destroy 1 random card in hand, but add 3 random Enhanced cards
column3: You're sacrificing a piece of honest evidence to introduce three deceptively powerful (enhanced) ones.

column1: Destroy 1 random card in hand, but add 2 random Enhanced cards
column3: A slightly less effective but still potent version of the above.

column1: Add a Gold Seal to 1 selected card
column3: A direct, illegal payment to make a piece of evidence financially valuable.

column1: Add Foil, Holographic, or Polychrome edition to a random card
column3: You're embellishing a piece of evidence to make it seem more important than it is.

column1: Creates a random Rare Partner, but sets money to $0
column3: You're taking on a huge, prestigious case (a Rare Partner) for free, betting the entire firm's resources on the future win.

column1: Converts all cards in hand to a single random suit
column3: You're forcing all the evidence in your hand to conform to a single, narrow narrative, regardless of the truth.

column1: Add Negative to a random Partner, but -1 Hand Size
column3: You've created a situation where one of your partners is now a liability (Negative), and the complexity of managing it reduces your overall capacity.

column1: Destroy 2 random cards in hand, but gain $20
column3: A direct, illegal act for a quick cash payout.

column1: Create a copy of 1 of your Partners at random, then destroy the original
column3: You've stolen the identity of a partner, creating a perfect replica but "destroying" the original's reputation in the process.

column1: Adds a Red Seal to 1 selected card
column3: You're convincing a witness to lie under oath, forcing them to "re-testify" (re-trigger) their statement.

column1: Adds Polychrome to a random Partner, and destroys the rest
column3: You're betting your entire case on one single, brilliant witness, sacrificing the rest of your team to make them shine.

column1: Adds a Blue Seal to 1 selected card
column3: You're creating a fake "landmark case" (Alchemy card) to support your argument.

column1: Adds a Purple Seal to 1 selected card
column3: You're discarding a piece of evidence to the media, which comes back as a new procedural advantage (Docket card).

column1: Create 2 exact copies (including Enhancements, Edition, and Seal) of a card
column3: You've created two perfect fakes of a crucial piece of evidence.

column1: Creates a Legendary Partner
column3: You've created the ultimate fake asset, a legendary partner who seems real.

column1: Upgrades every proof rule by one level
column3: The ultimate act of contempt: you're literally changing the fundamental rules of the game.
